data.title: Is Walt Disney Really Frozen Until They Find the Cure for Cancer?
data.meta_description: When Disney got sick, they put him in a coma inside a cryogenic chamber. The day our medical technology becomes so advanced we can reanimate people, he will come to life again. That’s what my mom…
data.text:
When Disney got sick, they put him in a coma inside a cryogenic chamber. The day our medical technology becomes so advanced we can reanimate people, he will come to life again. That’s what my mom told me when I was nine.

Over 50 years later, Disney’s body continues to float in liquid nitrogen, waiting for the cure. But with the recent breakthroughs in vaccines against cancer, the legendary creator can come back to life any day now.

Such news wouldn’t be spectacular from the scientific point of view only. All of us who grew up watching Disney’s magic animations would love to see the old guy return to the real world.

Except it won’t happen because the story about the reanimation of Uncle Walt is an urban myth.

Disney could do it all

Walt Disney (1901–1966) revolutionized cartoons with his multiplane camera to give depth to the picture. He gave us Mickey Mouse (1928) and created the first feature-length film Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937).

Disney had a great sense of business. Early in his career, he realized cartoons are not all about drawing. The audience wanted to feel. So, he…
